origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Program in American Culture.

did.unittitle: American Culture Folklore and Oral History Archives 2005-2009
did.abstract: Archives of folklore collected by students in the course "Survey of American Folklore" offered by the University of Michigan Program in American Culture and first taught by Bruce Conforth in 2005. Collected folklore reports compiled by students in American Folklore course based on oral interviews with informants. (Interviews are included on a variety of physical formats--cassettes, microcassettes, CDs, VHS tapes). Reports include essays, transcripts on topics ranging from popular folklore to campus legends and traditions.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Material was received in September 2010 (donor no. 8858).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: Not all informants authorized the use of their name in the interviews Closed files are noted with a {Restricted} note. Consult the release forms (in the Administration series) regarding use of the interviewee's name or consult the reference archivist.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, American Culture Folklore and Oral History Archives, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Program in American Culture offered an undergraduate survey course on American Folklore beginning in 2005. Professor Bruce Conforth began teaching the course. The course focused on the conventional beliefs, customs, traditions and rituals that shape culture as well as urban legends. Students in the survey course were taught fieldwork methodology and were assigned a folklore collection project. The collection projects required students to identify a folklore topic, conduct oral interviews and write a report and prepare transcripts of the interviews. The collection projects were then accessioned into the American Culture Folklore and Oral History Archives (originally housed in the Program in American Culture). In 2010 the archives of collected folklore was transferred to the Bentley Historical Library.

The folklore collection projects focused on an aspect of American folklore, which could range from a variety of topics. Students were given a large degree of independence in choosing their topic. Some of the most popular topics included traditions involving food, popular jokes, significant cultural objects, and customs and traditions surrounding the University of Michigan.

Interviewing informants comprised a large part of the project, as students had to interview at least one person (informant) as a source, although many students interviewed more than that. In many cases, the recording devices or tapes or discs containing the interviews were included along with the hardcopy reports. Transcripts of the interviews were also a part of the written report. Some students included photographs of the subject they were researching, and in rare cases the object itself is included in the collection.

Requirements for what should be included in the collection report evolved over the years. More recent projects include informant release forms, autobiographical sketches written by the student, as well as brief biographies about each of the informants.
Note: Not all informants authorized the use of their name in the interviews. Consult release forms regarding use of the interviewee's name.

scopecontent.p: The American Culture Folklore and Oral History Archives consists of folklore collection reports prepared by undergraduate students in the American Folklore course offered by the University of Michigan Program in American Culture. Prior to the transfer to the Bentley Historical Library, the folklore reports were organized according to general topics by students in the course and placed in archival folders and boxes under the direction of the professor. That order has been retained. Very often the media and objects included in the report have remained. The collection is meant to directly serve students who may take the Survey of American Folklore class in the future, and indirectly to those who, years from now, may re-discover and research aspects of American folklore that were pertinent during present day.

There is considerable overlap in subject matter between the categories of collecting topics. In the collection, folders for the first set of reports in a series are ordered according to their pre-assigned number (which can be found in the Administrative Files series) and not according to the last name of the student or title. For the second set, however, where no such number exists, the reports are ordered by surname of the student. In this finding aid, only the student's name and title of the report is listed. Further in the series names will appear to be in alphabetical order when the pre-assigned numbers were not continued.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Program in American Culture.
University of Michigan--Students--Social life and customs--2001-2010.

did.unittitle: Administrative Files

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files series consists of one box, with the folders labeled according to the genres/categories of papers that were written. These files contain "Accession Forms" for the American Culture Folklore Archives, and were filled out by hand for each report in the collection. They contain an assigned accession number (one number per report), the genre and sub-genre categories the report files under, as well as any keywords, presumably student-assigned, that relate to the report. The form also has a checklist for each type of material that was submitted along with the report (a list of informants, discs, audio cassettes, etc.), which may or may not have remained with the collection. The second page of the accession form asks for certain metadata from the student, such as the page length for certain documents, the condition of the accession, location, and number of informants. The forms in this series correspond with the first accession of reports that came as part of this collection. Not all reports in the collection may have an accession form or be recorded in the administrative files.

These files also contain the information on the release status for the collection reports. In some cases the collector and author of the reports has assigned some release limitations and in other cases the informants/interviewees have assigned release limitations (typically that their names not be used).

Computers

scopecontent.p: The Computers series consists of only two reports, which delve into the impact technology has on folk speech and communication.

did.unittitle: Ades, Rebecca, "The Impact of Technology on Folk Communication"
Kapordelis, Alexander -- "Texts from Last Night"
Cultural Objects

scopecontent.p: Cultural Objects reflects objects that are of special significance to the writer of the report. This could be for religious, historical, or personal reasons, among many others. Some examples include symbols of one's religion, ancestor's gravestones, or "The Rock" on the University of Michigan's campus. (This series was created separately by the processor of the collection to accommodate the lack of descriptor terms provided by students and to file several reports lacking an accession forms).

Customs

scopecontent.p: The Customs series is a very broad one, covering topics from formal events and topics that only occur annually or as part of a ceremonial tradition (such as "Maize Rage" at basketball games, family traditions, types of parties, rites of passage, singing groups, sports cheers, etc.) and are not part of daily life. It is different from the Cultural Objects series in that they are not religious or a singular object, but usually a repeated event that can be experienced by many individuals. However, the themes in this series very commonly overlap with attributes from other series. The kind of content in this series covers the gamut of most other series in this collection.

Customs -- Hash Bash

scopecontent.p: The Customs -- Hash Bash series covers subjects having to do with the annual promotion/celebration of reforming marijuana laws on the University of Michigan Diag, which occurs every first Saturday in April.

Folk Arts and Crafts

scopecontent.p: Folk Arts and Crafts includes a variety of hobbies and extracurricular activities practiced by students, such as collecting witchcraft objects, Civil War re-enacting, Tae Kwon Do, home brewing, and collecting guns.

scopecontent.p: Folk Dances contains only one report at this time, discussing modern American Swing Dance.

Folk Drama

scopecontent.p: Folk Drama currently consists of only one report, having to do with sideshows.

did.unittitle: Ostrander, John -- "Sideshows and Folk Performance of the Sensational"
Folk Games

scopecontent.p: Folk Games includes games of action and competitions that are not necessarily professional, but instead played as a leisurely activity or hobby. Some of these include fantasy baseball, various intramural teams, sports curses, and the University of Michigan diving team.

Folk Music

scopecontent.p: Folk Music contains two main subjects: music that is related to the University of Michigan, and then a set of reports about more general musical genres (hip-hop, The Grateful Dead, etc.)

Folk Songs

scopecontent.p: Folk Songs currently consists of only one report about the University of Michigan's student fight song "The Victors."

did.unittitle: Shaddy, Franklin -- " The Victors: Impressions and Anecdotes"
Folk Speech

scopecontent.p: Folk Speech features a variety of topics about slang and common speech used by students/individuals inherent to the University of Michigan or young people as a whole, and language usage that is generally not considered official in the English language. Some examples of topics covered include naming conventions in fraternities and sororities, slang, lingo, toast making among the Jewish community, conventions of sports radio broadcasters, and language used in stoner culture.

Folk Tales

scopecontent.p: The Folk Tales series greatly overlaps with the Legends series in terms of content. The subject matter can also be quite broad, with examples including tales surrounding specific dormitories on campus, general college life, drinking games, haunted houses, proverbs, and children's stories.

Food

scopecontent.p: The Food series covers a broad scope of topics regarding patterns of food consumption, and many reports discuss personal or familial ties to food. Many reports cover the history and preparation of certain types of regional food (Mexican, Jewish, Italian, Upper Peninsula of Michigan, eating habits in fraternities/sororities and athletes, etc.) Overall this category is very broad, and is one of the largest series in the collection.

Graffiti

scopecontent.p: Graffiti contains two reports at this time, discussing the presence of latrinalia, or bathroom graffiti, on the University of Michigan campus.

Sanchez, Pedro -- "A Study of Latrinalia at the University of Michigan"
Jokes

scopecontent.p: The Jokes series is one of the largest series in the collection. Instead of focusing on local customs, this series is more concerned with certain types of jokes that are present everywhere in American youth culture. Some examples included reports written on racial jokes, dirty/sexual jokes, Jewish jokes, "yo mama" jokes, and blonde jokes. There are multiple reports written on many of these topics.

Legends

scopecontent.p: The Legends series highly overlaps with Folk Tales in terms of subject matter, which can be quite broad. Some examples cover topics such as local legends, urban legends, and legends about the Diag at the University of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Jazwinski, Zoe -- "A Visit to the Shoe Tree: Exploring a Redford Tradition"
Kramer, Justin -- "University of Michigan Campus Legends"
Otto, Will -- "Foodway Urban Legends in the Culture of Fear"
Harris, Mary Beth -- "University of Michigan Legends and their Function"
Chan, Brandon K. -- "The University of Michigan :Variance in Campus Legends"
Superstitions

scopecontent.p: Superstitions is very similar to the Legends and Folk Tales series, since many of the reports cover topics with legend-like qualities, and are stories that are believed and shared by individuals but are not necessarily true fact. To differentiate between the series, Superstitions covers very general topics, such as superstitions about cheerleaders, ghosts, saying grace at meals, and pregnancy. Legends/Folk Tales cover more distinct and isolated events, and are not about general topics.

did.unittitle: Mueller, Amanda -- "UM Varsity Baseball, Football, and Men's Soccer Superstitions"
Maxbauer, Kaye -- "There Has To Be A Morning After: Hangover Folk Medicine at the University of Michigan"
Warnat, Amber -- "Analysis of the Superstitions of University of Michigan Cheerleaders"
Kasper, Casey -- "Ghosts in Stockwell Hall"
Kline, John -- "Grace and the Gender Roles, Tradition and Religion That Shape It"
Albain, Julia -- "The Ghost Light: Superstitions in the Theatre"
Wellerstein, Samantha -- "Pregnancy and Birth Folklore in a Medicalized Society"
